index.header: Interactive help on using the xMat

usage.header: How to use the xMat with ...
text: Please select from which program or programming language you want to use the xMat with:
By default, the following explicit Runge-Kutta methods are provided:
To select an integration scheme, edit the line
in the module General_Settings of the xMat. Replace Eul-Exp with the identifier of the integration method of your choice.

model_hypo.header: Which version of the hypoplastic constitutive model?

model_baro.header: Which version of the barodetic constitutive model?

text: • Defined in the PhD thesis from Wu (1992)
• Void ratio is the only state variable and has to be initialized accordingly
Each example uses the material parameters from densly packed Karlsuhe sand as published in Wu (1992), p. 22
All examples represent the same oedometric test: The initial stress is -10 kPa and is increased to -100 kPa, decreased to -50 kPa and increased again to -200 kPa. The initial void ratio is 0.65.
• Extension for intergranular strain from Niemunis and Herle (1997)
<li>Expects the following sixteen material parameters:<ul class="dotless twocolumns">
• 2-10: intergranular strain h11h_{11}, h22h_{22}, h33h_{33}, h12h_{12}, h21h_{21}, h23h_{23}, h32h_{32}, h13h_{13} and h31h_{31}
• Void ratio should be initialized as state variable. If it is not provided, it can optionally be passed as sixteenth material parameter instead

Each example uses the material parameters from Hostun sand as published in Schranz (2018), p. 66, with additional <math display="inline" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mi>ν</mi><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\nu</annotation></semantics></math>
All examples represent the same oedometric test: The initial stress is -10 kPa and is increased to -100 kPa, decreased to -50 kPa and increased again to -200 kPa. The initial void ratio is 0.7.
<li>Expects the following seven material parameters:<ul class="dotless twocolumns">
• Void ratio has to be initialized as a state variable.

Each example uses the material parameters from Hostun sand as published in Schranz (2018), p. 66, with negative <math display="inline" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c_3</annotation></semantics></math>
All examples represent the same oedometric test: The initial stress is -10 kPa and is increased to -100 kPa, decreased to -50 kPa and increased again to -200 kPa. The initial void ratio is 0.7.
• First defined in PhD thesis from Schranz (2018)
<li>Expects the following nine material parameters:<ul class="dotless twocolumns">
• Void ratio has to be initialized as a state variable.
Each example uses the material parameters from Hostun sand as published in Schranz (2018), p. 66
All examples represent the same oedometric test: The initial stress is -10 kPa and is increased to -100 kPa, decreased to -50 kPa and increased again to -200 kPa. The initial void ratio is 0.75.
• Defined in publication from Kolymbas (2021) with more details in Kolymbas (2022)
<li>Expects the following ten material parameters:<ul class="dotless twocolumns">
• 2: first part of the critical void ratio ec1e_{c1} and
• 3: second part of the critical void ratio ec2e_{c2}

<li>4-12: direction of the strain rate <math display="inline" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><msub><mover><mi>D</mi><mo accent="true">⃗</mo></mover><mn>11</mn></msub><annotation xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><msub><mover><mi>D</mi><mo accent="true">⃗</mo></mover><mn>33</mn></msub><annotation xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><msub><mover><mi>D</mi><mo accent="true">⃗</mo></mover><mn>21</mn></msub><annotation xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><msub><mover><mi>D</mi><mo accent="true">⃗</mo></mover><mn>32</mn></msub><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\vec{D}_{32}</annotation></semantics></math>, <math display="inline" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><msub><mover><mi>D</mi><mo accent="true">⃗</mo></mover><mn>13</mn></msub><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\vec{D}_{13}</annotation></semantics></math> and <math display="inline" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><msub><mover><mi>D</mi><mo accent="true">⃗</mo></mover><mn>31</mn></msub><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\vec{D}_{31}</annotation></semantics></math><li>
• Void ratio and first part of the critical void ratio have to be initialized as state variables.
Each example uses the material parameters from Hostun sand as published in Kolymbas (2022), p. 123
All examples represent the same oedometric test: The initial stress is -10 kPa and is increased to -100 kPa, decreased to -50 kPa and increased again to -200 kPa. The initial void ratio is 0.656.
To run a user subroutine with Abaqus, a fitting compiler has to be linked with Abaqus. Also for the xMat, an adjusted local environment file has to be provided.
To run a user subroutine with Abaqus, a fitting compiler has to be linked with Abaqus. Also for the xMat, an adjusted local environment file has to be provided.

abq_fortran_compiler.header: Checking if a Fortran compiler is linked with Abaqus
text: Open a console in Linux or a prepared command shell in Windows where abaqus can be executed. In Linux, enter
For Windows it might be required to navigate to the Abaqus commands directory first. Then enter
Abaqus should start and run a couple of tests including checks if a Fortran compiler is linked.
If no Fortran compiler is found or the tests are not working, please consult your Abaqus manual.

abq_environment_file.header: Set up a local environment file
text: Abaqus reads the system-wide environment files and afterwards a local environment file if present. The file is expected to be called abaqus_v6.env.
For using the xMat with Abaqus the compile_fortran command has to be provided and adjusted in that local file.
The recommended way is to copy the full command and needed variables from the system-wide environment file and adjust it.
The path to the system-wide environment file (relative to the Abaqus installation) should be for Linux
After copying the full compile_fortran command to the local environment file, add a line specifying to use the free source code format and pass the macro ABAQUS_CALLING.
Depending on the operating system and the compiler used, the actual flags might be different. For example, using the GNU Fortran compiler in Windows requires
Use the GNU Fortran compiler in Linux is slightly different and reads
As an example, a local environment file abaqus_v6.env for Linux with Intel Compiler should look similar to the following

import os
abaHomeInc = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.environ.get('ABA_HOME', ''), os.pardir))
compile_fortran = ['ifort',
                   '-V',
                   '-free', '-DABAQUS_CALLING', # <-- this line is important for use with xMat
                   '-c', '-fPIC', '-auto', '-mP2OPT_hpo_vec_divbyzero=F', '-extend_source',
                   '-fpp', '-WB', '-I%I',
                   '-I'+abaHomeInc, '%P',
                   ]
del abaHomeInc
For more information about using local environment files, please consult your Abaqus manual.

abq_std_sim.header: Examples to run oedmetric tests with Abaqus/Standard using the xMat
text: The following Python scripts can be used to create the input files. They have to be run in an interactive Abaqus session, e.g. by choosing File -> Run script, or in the console with
for Linux or from Windows with a command similar to

abaqus.bat script=Xmat_Oedo_hypo_vw96.py
(both assuming the script Xmat_Oedo_hypo_vw96.py is used).
The resulting input file can be run with Abaqus/Standard and the xMat interactively or like
for Linux. For Windows the executable has an extension like
Before running the simulation, make sure that Abaqus is linked with a Fortran compiler and an Abaqus environment file abaqus_v6.env is prepared for the xMat.
Also in the xMat file, ABQ_STD_CALLING has to be defined for ABAQUS_CALLING. More precisely, near the top of the file something like the following is needed:

Also in the xMat file, ABQ_EXP_CALLING has to be defined for ABAQUS_CALLING. More precisely, near the top of the file something like the following is needed:

To run a C program using the xMat, the xMat Fortran file has to be compiled as an object first and then linked to the program. For a single C file (e.g. Xmat_Oedo_hypo_vw96.c) this would be something similar to
for Linux with GCC or from Windows with Intel compiler similar to
As shown, it is important to define the macros CINTER and NOBIB next to the flags for free format and preprocessing when compiling.
The C code should use either the interface xmat_console_CInter or Dot_Values_CInter. The memory for input and output variables must also be managed on the C side.
Since xMat is also written in Fortran, this might work with just one compilation command. For a single Fortran file in free format (e.g. Xmat_Oedo_hypo_vw96.f) this would be something similar to
for Linux with GCC or from Windows with Intel compiler similar to
Make sure to include the flags for free format and preprocessing when compiling (as shown).
If the Fortran source file were in fixed format, first compile the xMat as an object file and then compile both to the final program.
It is assumed that the Fortran xmat_console interface is to be used. If the UMAT interface should be used instead, go to the page linked below.
Since xMat is also written in Fortran, this might work with just one compilation command. For a single Fortran file in free format (e.g. Xmat_Oedo_hypo_vw96.f) this would be something similar to
for Linux with GCC or from Windows with Intel compiler similar to
Make sure to include the flags for free format and preprocessing when compiling (as shown).
If the Fortran source file were in fixed format, first compile the xMat as an object file and then compile both to the final program.
It is assumed that the Fortran UMAT interface is to be used. If the xmat_console interface should be used instead, go to the page linked below.
To run the xMat from GNU Octave, it has to be compiled to an OCT file with a wrapper script first.

octave_compile.header: Compile xMat to an OCT file
text: First, a wrapper script is needed for compilation. The attached C++ code xmat_oct.cpp was successfully used for this. In Linux, the following commands were used within GNU Octave for compilation

Please note, that the path to the GNU Octave libraries (/usr/lib64/octave/6.4.0) needs to be adjusted according to your installation. In general, for compilation the macro OCTAVE_CALLING has be defined next to the flags for free format and preprocessing (as shown).
Before running the following scripts from GNU Octave, make sure that the xMat was successfully compiled to an OCT file with a wrapper script.
Then it should be possible to use the xMat from the provided scripts by simply running the scripts in GNU Octave.
To run the xMat from MATLAB, it has to be compiled as a MEX file first. From within MATLAB using GCC this can be done with
for Linux with GCC or from Windows with Intel compiler similar to
Please note, that for compilation the macro MATLAB_CALLING has to be defined next to the flags for free format and preprocessing (as shown).
After successfully compiling the xMat to a MEX file, it should be possible to use the xMat from the provided scripts by simply running the scripts in MATLAB.
To run the xMat from Python, it has to be compiled as a C library first. Here, an additional wrapper class will also be used to allow more flexible use.

text: To compile the xMat as a shared C library, use e.g.
for Linux with GCC or from Windows with Intel compiler something similar to
Please note, that for compilation the macro CINTER has to be defined next to the flags for free format, preprocessing and dynamic linking (as shown).

python_wrapper_class.header: Provide wrapper class to use the xMat from Python
text: The linked Python script provides a wrapper class named xMat in Python. The acutal xMat functions xmat_console_CInter and Dot_Values_CInter can be executed by using the member functions with the same name.
Before running the following scripts from Python, make sure that the xMat was successfully compiled as a C library and the wrapper class is used.
Then it should be possible to use the xMat from the provided scripts by simply running the scripts in Python.
To use the xMat from Plaxis, it has to be compiled as a dynamic-link library xmat64.dll first, e.g. with the Intel compiler like
Then the library xmat64.dll has to be moved or copied into the udsm directory in the Plaxis installation path.
Please note, that for compilation the macro PLAXIS_DLL has to be defined next to the flags for free format, preprocessing and dynamic library (as shown).

Afterwards, the xMat should be available as user defined material in Plaxis and all constitutive models from the xMat can be selected. Please note, that for some models it might be important to initialize some state variables or they will fail to run. State variables for the xMat can be defined in Plaxis below the specification of the material parameters.
